sub_topic: Calculation of the magnetic susceptibility of a material
message_1: A sample of iron has a density of 7.87 g/cm³ and a magnetic moment of 2.2 Bohr magneton per ion. Calculate the magnetic susceptibility of the iron at room temperature (25°C).
message_2:
To calculate the magnetic susceptibility of the iron sample, we need to determine the number of ions per unit volume and then use the Curie-Weiss law. 

First, let's find the number of ions per unit volume (n). The molar mass of iron (Fe) is 55.845 g/mol. 

Density (ρ) = Mass (m) / Volume (V)

We can rewrite this equation as:

Mass (m) = Density (ρ) × Volume (V)

Now, we can find the number of moles (n_moles) in the mass (m) of iron:

n_moles = Mass (m) / Molar mass (M)

Combining the two equations above, we get:

n_moles = Density (ρ) × Volume (V) / Molar mass (M)

Now, we can find the number of ions per unit volume (n):

n = n_moles × Avogadro's number (N_A) / Volume (V)

n = (Density (ρ) × Volume (V) / Molar mass (M)) × Avogadro's number (N_A) / Volume (V)

n = Density (ρ) × Avogadro's number (N_A) / Molar mass (M)

Now, we can plug in the values:

n = (7.87 g/cm³) × (6.022 × 10²³ ions/mol) / (55.845 g/mol)

n ≈ 8.49 × 10²² ions/cm³

Now, we can use the Curie-Weiss law to find the magnetic susceptibility (χ):

χ = (n × μ² × μ_B²) / (3 × k_B × T)

where μ is the magnetic moment per ion (2.2 Bohr magneton), μ_B is the Bohr magneton (9.274 × 10⁻²⁴ J/T), k_B is the Boltzmann constant (1.381 × 10⁻²³ J/K), and T is the temperature (25°C = 298 K).

χ = (8.49 × 10²² ions/cm³) × (2.2)² × (9.274 × 10⁻²⁴ J/T)² / (3 × 1.381 × 10⁻²³ J/K × 298 K)

χ ≈ 1.02 × 10⁻³ cm³/mol

The magnetic susceptibility of the iron sample at room temperature (25°C) is approximately 1.02 × 10⁻³ cm³/mol.
